featured.text: Carved from large, straight trees and painted vibrant colors, the totem poles are not just unique works of art.
Mortuary poles were also raised to honor the dead, but they differed from memorial poles, having a burial box placed at the top of the pole.
Traditionally, shame poles were carved for a chief to embarrass and ridicule another who had done something wrong.
Placed along the rear or front walls of a house, house poles also helped to support the main beam of the roof.

other.text: Inside the homes of high-ranking chiefs is where house poles were found.
The poles depicted the person’s accomplishments or family history.
While many of these poles can still be found in various locations on the west coast of North America, there is one pole that can now only be found in a museum—the shame pole.
Despite the threats posed by cultural and political encroachment of colonial forces, the art of totem pole carving has survived.
Memorial poles stood in front of a house.
The family’s history was carefully carved into each pole.
How is the information about totem poles organized in Paragraphs 2 to 4? (A)
Once the wrong was made right, the pole was taken down.
The coastal peoples have long passed on knowledge from generation to generation through oral traditions, and totem poles were the traditional way of telling the story of an individual family or clan.
Totem poles are important expressions of specific Aboriginal cultures.
The totem pole can be grouped into specific categories, depending on its location and the occasion for which it was carved.

definition.zh_def: 一根長而直的物體，通常用於支撐或作為標記。
definition.en_def: A long, slender object, often used for support or as a marker.
definition.example: The flag was raised on a tall pole.
